Authors:
Sebastian Anton Manfred Werner, Derek Persoh, Gerhard
Rambold
Title: New aspects of the biology of Mortierella alliacea
Keywords:
Fungi, Acari, mites, ITS rRNA gene, lectotypification,
Leptogamasus obesus, Oppiella subpectinata
Abstract:
Environmental PCR revealed a fungal genotype related to
Mortierella alliacea as living epi- or endozoically associated to the
mite species Leptogamasus obesus and Oppiella subpectinata, as well as
in the soil body. Pure cultures of a newly isolated genotypically
corresponding strain were examined to gain deeper insight into the
biology of this scarcely known species. Morphological and physiological
traits, as well as molecular data confirmed an affiliation to
Mortierella alliacea Linnemann. However, the strain showed minor
morphological differences to the original description of M. alliacea
(selected here as lectotype) and to the isolate CBS 894.68 (selected
here as epitype) with regard to sporocystospore and chlamydospore
morphology. Therefore, an emended species description is provided in the
present article. The psychrotolerant fungus is able to grow at
temperatures between 0 °C and 25 °C. It lacks the capability to degrade
starch, cellulose, lignin, chitin, and lipids. Proteolytic activity was
only exhibited at 4 °C. Co-incubated mites were not affected by the
fungus, indicating that the mites predominantly serve as vectors. The
fungus limited degradation capabilities suggest that it lives on readily
accessible carbohydrates in soil.
